Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as d5fb584a8ad7d493a3236261f727852f262271c6

15 is the latest approved patch-set.
No files were changed between the latest approved patch-set and the submitted one.
This needs set in the context construction.
Closing out.  This is a core issue of not using the right method.

Can we make this two methods please?  There can be other methods for the overlap, but as is, this is setting a lot of parameters that aren't required in a client context.

For example, it's using the webserver private key as the key, not a client key.  These are different, and we need to code to comprend that.

Other example, setting alpnSelectProtoCallback on a client context makes no sense.  We don't support http2, nor do we need to advertise as the client.

TL; DR;  Please make these two methods, one for client, and one for server.



I typed the above, then realized that getSSLClientContext already exists?  Why are we trying to overwrite it?
Closing out.  This is already two methods, this patchset just ignores that.  Will resolve in other thread.
This needs changed for client.
Nvm, something more important.

lets just remove this from the commit message;  Mutual TLS itself as implemented here doesn't identify the bmc as a special user.  Some future implementation that adds multiple root certificates might, but lets push that to a later time.
I was giving some examples for the MTLS use cases. One of the use case is redfish aggregation where we use CN from certificate to create user session. I can remove it if it is confusing.

My point is that THIS commit doesn't implement that, so it's confusing.  If you made it clear that in the future we might do that, it would be fine to keep, but I think it's just easier to remove.  This patchset can stand on its own.
Removed
Done

why does bmc needs to create self signed client certificates?
mtls certificates will be expected to be uploaded on BMC by user while configuring MTLS right?

what happens if the certificate is not present in the expected path? 
What is the fallback?
I have already said that , this self signed certificate is of no use. It is there as a fallback. 
We have two choice
1) place self signed certificate 
or
2) check the presence of certificate in the path, then decide whether MTLS should be enabled in client ssl context or not.
I am open for any of these approach.

> what happens if the certificate is not present in the expected path?

The fallback should be to connect without an client certificate, the same as how we do today.  That path needs to work anyway, because not all servers will be enabled for client connections.
Acknowledged

Hardcoded "root" user implies that users will be using the root user, which defeats your earlier point about identifying the bmc as a special user.  The common name in the Certificate should determine the user, and because we don't have control of the certificate signing (only a CA has that) we can just take whatever user was signed by the CA when the client certificate is configured.

We should not generate a self-signed client cert.  There's no point, as it won't be trusted by any implementation given there's no public CA, as you point out.  If strong mtls verification is not enabled, no client cert is the same as an untrusted client cert.

There is no self signed certificate for client. Assumption is that the CA certified client.pem should have valid CN if that is to be used for aggregation session.
Provisioning flow will take care of it. Http_client need not have any business here
Done

How?  With the goal of not making this patch huge, I'm happy to push this to another patch, but we need some kind of indication of how you expect this to work.  Right now, simply self signing a certificate can't prove that we've implemented mtls correctly.

If you tested this by provisioning certificates by hand, say that.

I have added the detailed testing step in the commit. Yes did a manual certificate provisioning done . I mean copied CA certified entity certificates in /etc/ssl/certs/https folder . And placed corresponding root CA in /etc/ssl/certs/authority folder. 

Tested various scenarios
Done

originated. 

I suspect this is your CI fail

    Running shellcheck
    commit_gitlint: FAILED
    commit_spelling: FAILED

now that we're not generating it at connection time, if the client tls certificate is updated, how is it picked up?  I suspect this optimization causes new connections to be created with the old certificate when it's updated.
I was expecting a restart of bmcweb if any certificate changes. The same argument goes to server certificate also right? How does new server certificate getting picked up?

no, bmcweb for server certificates picks them up without dropping connections or requiring a restart.  I’d expect similar here.

take a look at how bmcweb handles HUP and it will make more sense.

How? I could see loadCertificate called from startAsyncWaitForSignal , which is triggered by tls property changes. Here we are cancelling acceptor. Aren't we supposed to call doAccept again? or are you saying that async_accept will take care of this?

I think I can use same logic here too. Only issue is how do we get to know about certificate change? In both server and client certificate case I don't see any monitoring happening for certificate file update. Am I missing something here?

> How? I could see loadCertificate called from startAsyncWaitForSignal , which is triggered by tls property changes. Here we are cancelling acceptor. Aren't we supposed to call doAccept again? or are you saying that async_accept will take care of this?

You ask how, they you point out the code where we do it.  The gist is that we track certificates as shared pointers, and we replace the "main" shared pointer when we have a new certificate.

> 
> I think I can use same logic here too. Only issue is how do we get to know about certificate change? In both server and client certificate case I don't see any monitoring happening for certificate file update. Am I missing something here?

it would be HUP, just another callback in startAsyncWaitForSignal

note, canceling the acceptor is just because the first connection is constructed before the accept call.  Arguably we could organize that code better so the cancel isn't required, but canceling was the easiest thing.

Actually, for the client case, I think it also needs to include some variation of the client certificate (hash or something) in the clientKey, so that we differentiate connections with the right cert with ones that have the wrong cert.

When we change a certificate, that client key will change, which will cause a new connection to be opened instead of reusing the old, and we'll get a new connection.  In this way we will also be able to support per-subscription keys.
Acknowledged

Are you suggesting that we need to disconnect all keep_alive connection created, if there is a certificate change? Now I have modified the code to pick latest client certificate whenever a new connection is made. Caching the ssl context logic is removed

> Are you suggesting that we need to disconnect all keep_alive connection created, if there is a certificate change?

Not explicitly, but that's what will happen if the connections stop being used.

> Now I have modified the code to pick latest client certificate whenever a new connection is made. Caching the ssl context logic is removed
Done
What is a "developer test"
Ran manual test execution by the developer to test aggregation using MTLS certificate
right, so give some details about what you did manually.  just putting “developer test” doesn’t help someone to replicate your results
Acknowledged

Describe this better than "worked well" please.

Were you testing against bmcweb as an aggregation source, or something else?
What was your aggregation topology like?
did you run the service validator?
did you load a bad (untrusted) certificate and verify the connection was rejected, and we returned the correct error code?
Did you test AggregationSource returned the correct data?
please update test results here
Done
Done
why was this removed?
It is done below in loadCertificate.
I don't understand your answer.  loadCertificate now calls ensureCertificate, not getSSLClientContext

after that getSsl context function is called. 
Any way I am rewriting the code to avoid sslcontext reuse
I see ensuressl::getSslContext being called, but not getSSLClientContext
Modified code to use clientContext
Done
why weak_ptr here?

Yes this has to be changed now as per you comment below for reloading certificate run time.
What is your opinion about the reusing the ssl context. It may have some advantage for the retry paths and large number of connections.

Is the complexity worth the performance benefit we get?

I'd expect this to be shared-ptr, not weak_ptr.  Why is it weak ptr?


> What is your opinion about the reusing the ssl context.

I'd be surprised if it was a significant performance benefit.  They're pretty cheap to construct I think?  It might save memory, but we're creating 10s of connections, not 1000s, so I doubt it will matter.
Acknowledged
We shouldn't try to lock the context if we're not in ssl mode.
true. will change it
moved back to previous implementation
Done
unrelated whitespace change.
Done
This is reading the certificate from current working directory.  Shouldn't we be reading from somewhere specific?
yes it has been done by the ensureCertificate function
Right, which isn't really correct to the system.
check the new implementation. Removed the self signed certificate creation for client
Done
Root seems odd for this call?

Yes , I kept it as root to start a discussion over that. How do think it should be done? Dont we create a default self signed certificate with some CN? We have done it for server certificate('testhost') . Shouldn't we do the same for client? Are we open for a meson variable for this?

> Dont we create a default self signed certificate with some CN?

the CN for the server cert is "TestHost" and is only used because if you don't have a server cert, no client can connect.  For client auth, we should just not use a client cert if one isn't available;  Client certs are not required, only server certs.

> Are we open for a meson variable for this?

I fear that you're not understanding how mutual TLS provisioning works;

Mutually trusted entity creates a private key, and a certificate authority.

Either with a CSR from the BMC, or with a newly made private, CA (off BMC) creates and signs a certificate for mutual authentication.  Certificate will include the common name (username) that the BMC is authorized to use.

CA gives cert, or cert+private key to BMC

BMC connects using cert.

At no point does this involve the BMC itself deciding on its username, the CA decides that.

I did exactly what you described in my testing. 
My question was not around how MTLS works.
MTLS is the property of both server and client. Even if client provides certificates, it is up to the server to decide on if MTLS should be enabled or not. 
In our case we have use cases for http clients to talk to non MTLS servers. Whether a server is MTLS enabled or not is not decided by the http_client. 

So rather than giving a runtime configuration to decide on usage of client certificate,I thought it is better to assume that there is a client.pem always available in specified dir. Bmc can always override the certificate by installing a CA signed entity certificate with same name.  My implementation is done based on that.

Since we have self signed client certificate now , we wanted to decide on what should be the CN for it. This CN can be one of the bmcuser name which already has some privileges , which will be helpful in developer testing for aggregation. 

So I was asking should we hardcode the CN or take it from compiler generated variable?

I am ok with not having default certificate generation. But that make some more checks in code to see if certificate available or client_MTLS feature flag enabled etc.
I agree with Ed here, there is no point in deciding username in BMC itself.
this is needed only if we implement fallback self signed client certificate.

I decided on the self signed certificate , because bmcweb is not strictly validating the client certificate. It just uses the CN to create user session.
I thought that there may be  cases for aggregator to work with weaker mtls validation

> So rather than giving a runtime configuration to decide on usage of client certificate,I thought it is better to assume that there is a client.pem always available in specified dir.

We need to store the client certificate in phosphor-certificate-manager, so that the Redfish CertificateCollection things work.


> we wanted to decide on what should be the CN for it.

For a self signed client certificate, the CN doesn't matter, there is nothing that trusts the certificate, so the CN can just be empty string.

But again, if a client certificate hasn't been provisioned, we should not generate a self signed one.  There's no point.
Acknowledged
Why are we modifying the server certificate creation routines?  We already have client certificate creation routines here.
most of the code are same. Will refactor the code to have a reusable part and serve/client specific parts.
refactored the code. please review
Done

I've made all the changes that I think need made, including adding comments about certain paths being temporary.

Please take a look and see if it works for you, and please review the other patch that's now in the stack above this one.

This now looks like an unrelated refactor?

I guess that's fine, but ideally in the future try to put your refactoring commits in a separate commit from new functionality.
Done

Why were these removed?  This list is different than the other one, so you've changed behavior without documenting it.

FWIW, I do have patches in review to make these the same, but we need to be explicit about doing it, rather than just doing it in a refactor.
Fixed these back to what they were.
This functiond doesn't seem like the right one to be calling for client certs.  If a client cert doesn't exist, we don't want to create one.  You might want to instead call verifyOpensslKeyCert?
Done
Done
Why is this needed?
Done

Just FYI, I have some refactors of these functions coming as well in:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/70295. WE'll get the merge conflicts figured out, but just be aware.
Done
This looks like it was changed from a full path to a partial path?
I see, path was constructed in the function.  New code now goes back to fixed path.

Added in prior commit.
Just waiting on the prior commit to get reviewed.

I went through the code. The changes are done to return optional for clientContext and shared_ptr for servercontext. Then we don't have any change in http_client. I was thinking on same line. I am ok with the change.
Please review https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/70295, then both these can merge.
